sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• Febrile neutropenia, In nonmyeloid malignancies after myelosuppressive chemotherapy; Prophylaxis: 6 mg subQ for each chemotherapy cycle administered approximately 24 hours after cytotoxic chemotherapy
  • Neutropenia (Severe), In nonmyeloid malignancies after myelosuppressive chemotherapy; Prophylaxis: 6 mg subQ for each chemotherapy cycle administered approximately 24 hours after cytotoxic chemotherapy

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono: safety and efficacy of lipegfilgrastim not established in pediatric patients up to 17 years of age

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
  • Febrile neutropenia, In nonmyeloid malignancies after myelosuppressive chemotherapy; Prophylaxis
  • Neutropenia (Severe), In nonmyeloid malignancies after myelosuppressive chemotherapy; Prophylaxis

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: Hypersensitivity to lipegfilgrastim or any component of the product

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Endocrine and Metabolic:
  • -- Patients with hereditary fructose intolerance; not recommended
  • -- Hypokalemia may occur; monitoring recommended for patients at increased risk
  • Hematologic:
  • -- Anemia may occur; monitoring recommended
  • -- Anti-lipegfilgrastim antibodies may form and lead to adverse events or loss of efficacy
  • -- Capillary leak syndrome has been reported
  • -- Leukocytosis may occur; monitoring recommended and discontinuation may be necessary
  • -- Patients with chronic or secondary acute myeloid leukemia; not recommended
  • -- Patients with myelodysplastic syndromes; not recommended
  • -- Reversible thrombocytopenia may occur; monitoring recommended
  • -- Sickle cell crisis has been reported in patients with sickle cell anemia; monitoring recommended
  • -- Splenic rupture (including fatal cases) has been reported; monitoring recommended
  • -- Splenomegaly has been reported; monitoring recommended
  • Immunologic:
  • -- Hypersensitivity to granulocyte colony stimulating factor or derivatives; risk of cross-sensitivity; not recommended
  • Respiratory:
  • -- Pulmonary adverse reactions (eg, interstitial pneumonia, acute respiratory distress syndrome) have been reported; discontinuation may be necessary
  • Other:
  • -- Patients on cytotoxic chemotherapy; not recommended within 24 hours of administration or to increase chemotherapy dose beyond established regimens

sub.title: Pregnancy Category
sub.mono: Fetal risk cannot be ruled out. (TH)

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Cardiovascular:Chest pain (1% to less than 10%)
  • Endocrine metabolic:Hypokalemia (1% to less than 10%)
  • Musculoskeletal:Musculoskeletal pain (10% or greater)
  • Neurologic:Headache (1% to less than 10%)
Serious
  • Hematologic:Capillary leak syndrome, Rupture of spleen, Sickle cell anemia with crisis, Splenomegaly, Thrombocytopenia (1% to less than 10%)
  • Immunologic:Hypersensitivity reaction (0.1% to less than 1%)

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Lipegfilgrastim is a recombinant human granulocyte-colony stimulating factor consisting of filgrastim conjugated with a polyethylene glycol molecule joined via a carbohydrate linker allowing it have sustained duration as a stimulator of the proliferation of hematopoietic progenitor cells, other single lineage and multilineage progenitors, and pluripotent hematopoietic stem cells; a stimulator of differentiation into mature cells; and their release into peripheral blood.

0.title: Absorption
0.mono: Tmax, subQ: 8 to 48 hours (depending on chemotherapy and cycle)

2.title: Metabolism
2.mono: Intra- and extracellular degradation via proteolytic enzymes

4.title: Elimination Half Life
4.mono: 28 to 42 hours (depending on chemotherapy and cycle)

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Subcutaneous
  • remove the prefilled syringe from the refrigerator (must be used within 3 days of removal) and allow solution to reach a comfortable temperature (15 to 25 degrees C) before injection
  • avoid vigorously shaking
  • inject subQ into the abdomen, upper arm, or thigh
  • prefilled syringes are for single use only; discard any unused drug

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• improvement in absolute neutrophil count or reduced neutrophil recovery time is indicative of efficacy
  • decreased incidence and duration of neutropenia-related sequelae (eg, fever, infections) are indicative of efficacy
  • anti-drug antibodies, in patients who fail to respond to treatment
  • platelet count, hematocrit, and WBC count; regularly during therapy
  • appropriate laboratory tests, in patients with sickle cell anemia
  • serum potassium levels, in patients at risk for hypokalemia due to underlying disease or concomitant medications
  • spleen size
  • signs and symptoms of sickle cell crisis, including splenic enlargement and vasoocclusive crisis, in patients with sickle cell anemia

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Advise patient to report symptoms of interstitial pneumonia or acute respiratory distress syndrome.
  • Counsel patient to report symptoms of anemia or thrombocytopenia.
  • Side effects may include musculoskeletal pain (bone, joint, or muscle), chest pain, headaches, rash, or skin redness.
  • Instruct patient to report symptoms of splenic rupture.
  • Teach patient proper technique and placement of injections (abdomen, upper arm, or thigh).
